section_name: 01 You only have 10 seconds to show you're a somebody
chapter_summary: Don't smile immediately when greeting someone. Instead, pause for a second, look at their face, and then let a big, warm smile flood over your face and into your eyes. The delay makes your smile appear more genuine and personalized.

section_name: 01 You only have 10 seconds to show you're a somebody
chapter_summary: Pretend your eyes are glued to your conversation partner's with warm taffy. Maintain eye contact even after they finish speaking, and when you must look away, do it slowly and reluctantly. This conveys feelings of respect and fondness.

section_name: 01 You only have 10 seconds to show you're a somebody
chapter_summary: Watch your target person even when someone else is speaking. This powerfully communicates that you are extremely interested in their reactions and can't take your eyes off them.

section_name: 01 You only have 10 seconds to show you're a somebody
chapter_summary: The perfect posture will help you captivate the crowd.

section_name: 01 You only have 10 seconds to show you're a somebody
chapter_summary: The moment you are introduced to someone, give them a warm smile and turn your body 100 percent towards them, offering your undivided attention as you would to a small child.

section_name: 01 You only have 10 seconds to show you're a somebody
chapter_summary: When you meet someone new, imagine they are an old friend you are happily reunited with. This triggers a chain reaction of warm and positive body language, from your eyebrows to your toes.

section_name: 01 You only have 10 seconds to show you're a somebody
chapter_summary: In any important conversation, do not fidget, twitch, squirm, or touch your face. Such movements can give the impression that you are fibbing or that something isn't right.

section_name: 01 You only have 10 seconds to show you're a somebody
chapter_summary: While you are talking, also keep a keen eye on how your listener is reacting to what you are saying. Then, plan your next moves based on their reactions.

chapter_name: 09 Watch the Scene Before You Make the Scene
section_name: 01 You only have 10 seconds to show you're a somebody
chapter_summary: Before an event, visualize yourself walking with great posture, smiling, making eye contact, and chatting comfortably with everyone. This mental rehearsal helps it all happen automatically.

section_name: 02 How to Know What to Say After You Say "Hi"
chapter_summary: Before speaking, take a "voice sample" of your listener to understand their state of mind and match their mood and tone.

section_name: 02 How to Know What to Say After You Say "Hi"
chapter_summary: Don't worry about your first words, as 80 percent of a listener's impression is non-verbal. No matter how ordinary the words, a passionate delivery and positive demeanor will make you sound exciting.

section_name: 02 How to Know What to Say After You Say "Hi"
chapter_summary: When you go to a gathering, wear or carry something unusual to give people an excuse to approach you and start a conversation.

section_name: 02 How to Know What to Say After You Say "Hi"
chapter_summary: Ask the host of a party or event to introduce you to someone you want to meet, or ask them for a few facts you can use as an icebreaker.

section_name: 02 How to Know What to Say After You Say "Hi"
chapter_summary: Stand near a group you wish to join and listen to their conversation. When you have something to contribute, jump in by saying, "Excuse me, I couldn't help but overhear...".

section_name: 02 How to Know What to Say After You Say "Hi"
chapter_summary: When asked where you are from, never give a one-word answer. Share some engaging facts about your hometown that your conversation partner can comment on.

section_name: 02 How to Know What to Say After You Say "Hi"
chapter_summary: When asked what you do, expand on your job title with interesting details to give your new acquaintance something to talk about.

section_name: 02 How to Know What to Say After You Say "Hi"
chapter_summary: When introducing people, don't just state their names. Provide a "conversational hook," like a shared hobby or interest, to help get them talking.

section_name: 02 How to Know What to Say After You Say "Hi"
chapter_summary: Listen closely to every word your conversation partner says for clues to their preferred topics, then steer the conversation in that direction.

section_name: 02 How to Know What to Say After You Say "Hi"
chapter_summary: Imagine a large spotlight between you and your conversation partner. When they are speaking, shine it on them; the longer you keep the focus off yourself, the more interesting they will find you.

section_name: 02 How to Know What to Say After You Say "Hi"
chapter_summary: To avoid being speechless, simply repeat the last few words your conversation partner said. This puts the ball back in their court and prompts them to continue.

section_name: 02 How to Know What to Say After You Say "Hi"
chapter_summary: When you are with someone important to you in a group, ask them to retell an enjoyable story by saying, "Tell them about the time you...".

section_name: 02 How to Know What to Say After You Say "Hi"
chapter_summary: When you first meet someone, save your skeletons for later in the relationship and focus on positive topics.

chapter_name: 23 The Latest News | Don't Leave Home Without It
section_name: 02 How to Know What to Say After You Say "Hi"
chapter_summary: Knowing the big-deal news happened today will rescue you from having no clue what everybody’s talking about.

section_name: 03 How to talk like the big boys 'n' girls
chapter_summary: A sign of a "Somebody" is the absence of the question, "What do you do?". Instead, ask a more gracious question like, "How do you spend most of your time?".

section_name: 03 How to talk like the big boys 'n' girls
chapter_summary: Just as you would tailor a written resume, tailor the verbal description of your professional life to match the interests of each listener.

section_name: 03 How to talk like the big boys 'n' girls
chapter_summary: Improve your vocabulary by looking up common words you use daily and substituting them with a few new, more interesting words to enrich your vocabulary.

section_name: 03 How to talk like the big boys 'n' girls
chapter_summary: If you share an interest with someone, the longer you wait to reveal it, the more impressed they will be, as you will come across as more confident.

section_name: 03 How to talk like the big boys 'n' girls
chapter_summary: Start sentences with the word "you" whenever appropriate. It grabs your listener's attention and gets a more positive response.

section_name: 03 How to talk like the big boys 'n' girls
chapter_summary: When meeting a group of people, give each person a distinct and specific smile rather than one generic smile for everyone.

chapter_name: 30 Don't Touch a Cliché with a Ten-Foot Pole
section_name: 03 How to talk like the big boys 'n' girls
chapter_summary: Avoid using clichés when talking with successful people.

section_name: 03 How to talk like the big boys 'n' girls
chapter_summary: Read books by public speakers to find memorable quotes, pearls of wisdom, and clever phrases that you can use in your own conversations.

section_name: 03 How to talk like the big boys 'n' girls
chapter_summary: Don't hide behind euphemisms. Big winners use direct, clear language and are not afraid of "real words".

section_name: 03 How to talk like the big boys 'n' girls
chapter_summary: Never make a joke at someone else's expense. It is a dead giveaway of a "little cat" and will cause "big cats" to look down on you.

section_name: 03 How to talk like the big boys 'n' girls
chapter_summary: Before delivering any news, consider how the receiver will take it, and deliver it with the appropriate emotion—a smile, a sigh, or a sob—for them.

section_name: 03 How to talk like the big boys 'n' girls
chapter_summary: When someone keeps asking you about a topic you don't want to discuss, simply repeat your initial response using the exact same words and tone of voice.

section_name: 03 How to talk like the big boys 'n' girls
chapter_summary: When talking with a celebrity, don't compliment their work directly; instead, mention the pleasure or insight it has given you, and focus on a recent accomplishment.

section_name: 03 How to talk like the big boys 'n' girls
chapter_summary: Do not let the phrase "thank you" stand alone. Always follow it with "for," specifying what you are grateful for.

section_name: 04 How to be an insider in any crowd
chapter_summary: Once a month, do something you would never normally do, like attend a lecture or sport outside your usual interests, to get 80 percent of the right lingo from just one exposure.

section_name: 04 How to be an insider in any crowd
chapter_summary: "Jobbledygook" is the language of other professions. Learning a few key phrases or opening questions makes you sound like an insider.

section_name: 04 How to be an insider in any crowd
chapter_summary: Before meeting people from a particular industry, find out what the current hot-button issues or burning concerns are in their field and bring them up in conversation.

section_name: 04 How to be an insider in any crowd
chapter_summary: To learn about any profession or hobby, read the monthly magazines and trade publications that serve their specific interest.

section_name: 04 How to be an insider in any crowd
chapter_summary: Before visiting a foreign country, get a book on international dos and taboos to avoid making a cultural gaffe with gestures, gifts, or compliments.

section_name: 04 How to be an insider in any crowd
chapter_summary: For big-ticket items, learn a few words of industry jargon from several vendors before going to the one you plan to buy from to help you negotiate a lower price.

section_name: 05 Why, we're just alike!
chapter_summary: Observe the way people move—fast, slow, fluid, jerky—and subtly imitate their style of movement to make them feel subliminally comfortable with you.

section_name: 05 Why, we're just alike!
chapter_summary: Listen to your partner's specific choice of words—nouns, verbs, adjectives—and echo them back. Hearing their own words come from your mouth creates subliminal rapport.

section_name: 05 Why, we're just alike!
chapter_summary: Use analogies and imagery from your listener's world and interests, not your own, to give your points more power and punch.

section_name: 05 Why, we're just alike!
chapter_summary: Instead of unconscious sounds like "uh huh," use complete sentences to show your understanding, such as "I see what you mean" or "That's a lovely thing to say".

section_name: 05 Why, we're just alike!
chapter_summary: Listen to whether your partner is speaking in visual, auditory, or kinesthetic terms and match your empathizers accordingly to make them feel you see, hear, or feel the world the way they do.

section_name: 05 Why, we're just alike!
chapter_summary: Create a sensation of intimacy with someone new by using words like "we," "us," and "our" early in the conversation.

section_name: 05 Why, we're just alike!
chapter_summary: When you have a shared moment with a new acquaintance, find a few words to refer back to it later. This creates a sense of shared history between you.

section_name: 06 The power of praise, the folly of flattery
chapter_summary: A compliment that is overheard is more powerful than one given directly. Tell a mutual friend something positive about someone so they "overhear" it, which adds credibility.

section_name: 06 The power of praise, the folly of flattery
chapter_summary: Become a carrier of good news. When you hear something complimentary about someone, fly to them and deliver the compliment.

section_name: 06 The power of praise, the folly of flattery
chapter_summary: Make comments that presuppose something positive about the person you're talking with.

section_name: 06 The power of praise, the folly of flattery
chapter_summary: Become an "undercover complimenter" by sneaking praise into the parenthetical part of your sentence, making it seem as if it just slipped out.

section_name: 06 The power of praise, the folly of flattery
chapter_summary: Search for one specific, unique, and attractive quality in a person. At the end of your conversation, look them in the eye, say their name, and deliver the compliment.

section_name: 06 The power of praise, the folly of flattery
chapter_summary: Regularly caress your friends, colleagues, and loved ones with small verbal affirmations like "Nice job!" or "Well done!" to let them know you appreciate them.

section_name: 06 The power of praise, the folly of flattery
chapter_summary: The moment someone finishes a feat, praise them immediately with a quick, reflexive "You were terrific!".

section_name: 06 The power of praise, the folly of flattery
chapter_summary: When you receive a compliment, let it boomerang back to the giver by quickly murmuring something like, "That's very kind of you".

section_name: 06 The power of praise, the folly of flattery
chapter_summary: Ask people what they'd want on their tombstone to learn their deepest self-image. Later, use their own words to compliment them, making them feel truly understood.

section_name: 07 Direct dial their hearts
chapter_summary: When you're on the phone, you must turn your smiles, nods, and gestures into sounds and words your listener can hear, punching up your energy by about 30 percent.

section_name: 07 Direct dial their hearts
chapter_summary: On the phone, use the other person's name more often than you would in person to keep their attention and create a sense of closeness.

section_name: 07 Direct dial their hearts
chapter_summary: Answer the phone professionally, but after you hear who is calling, let a huge smile of happiness flood into your voice to make the caller feel special.

section_name: 07 Direct dial their hearts
chapter_summary: If you screen calls, have your staff first say, "Oh yes, I'll put you right through. May I tell her who's calling?" before returning to say you're unavailable. This makes callers feel less personally rejected.

section_name: 07 Direct dial their hearts
chapter_summary: When calling someone's home or office, always be friendly and respectful to the person who answers the phone, such as a spouse or secretary, as they can influence the VIP.

section_name: 07 Direct dial their hearts
chapter_summary: Always begin a phone call by asking about the person's timing, with a question like, "Is this a convenient time for you to talk?".

section_name: 07 Direct dial their hearts
chapter_summary: To be perceived as reliable, leave a short, professional outgoing voicemail message and change it every day.

section_name: 07 Direct dial their hearts
chapter_summary: When you get an answering machine, treat the beep as your cue to deliver a compelling, ten-second "audition" that proves you are worthy of a quick callback.

section_name: 07 Direct dial their hearts
chapter_summary: To signal to a secretary that you are friends with their boss, casually use the pronoun "he" or "she" instead of their full name, for example, "Hi, is she in?".

section_name: 07 Direct dial their hearts
chapter_summary: When you hear a background noise on a call (another phone, a baby crying), stop speaking and ask the person if they need to attend to it.

section_name: 07 Direct dial their hearts
chapter_summary: Record your business conversations and listen to them a second or third time to pick up on significant subtleties you may have missed in the moment.

section_name: 08 How to work a party like a politician works a room
chapter_summary: At a party, either eat or socialize, but do not do both at once. Holding food or a drink creates a barrier between you and the person you are talking to.

section_name: 08 How to work a party like a politician works a room
chapter_summary: When you arrive at a gathering, stop dramatically in the doorway and slowly survey the entire scene to diagnose the situation you are walking into.

chapter_name: 73 Be the Chooser, Not the Choosee
section_name: 08 How to work a party like a politician works a room
chapter_summary: Don't stand around waiting for people to approach you. Actively explore every face in the room and decide who you want to capture in your life.

section_name: 08 How to work a party like a politician works a room
chapter_summary: Keep your body in an open position, especially your arms and hands. People are drawn to open palms, which signal acceptance and that you have nothing to hide.

section_name: 08 How to work a party like a politician works a room
chapter_summary: Keep track of the tiniest details of your conversation partners' lives and refer to them in later conversations. This creates a powerful sense of intimacy and makes them feel like a star.

section_name: 08 How to work a party like a politician works a room
chapter_summary: Immediately after talking with someone, write notes on the back of their business card about your conversation—their interests, a joke they told, etc.—to reference in your next communication.

section_name: 08 How to work a party like a politician works a room
chapter_summary: Pay close attention to your customers' non-verbal signals to see which aspects of your product thrill them and which bore them, then adjust your pitch accordingly.

chapter_name: 78 See No Bloopers, Hear No Bloopers
section_name: 09 Little tricks of big winners
chapter_summary: When friends or colleagues make minor fumbles, spills, or slips, pretend you do not notice them to spare their feelings.

section_name: 09 Little tricks of big winners
chapter_summary: When someone's story is interrupted, help them resume by saying, "Now please get back to your story," or even better, by asking, "So what happened after..." and filling in the last few words for them.

section_name: 09 Little tricks of big winners
chapter_summary: Whenever you ask for a favor or suggest a meeting, be upfront about what's in it for you (WIIFM) and what's in it for them (WIIFY).

section_name: 09 Little tricks of big winners
chapter_summary: When a friend does you a favor, give them at least 24 hours to enjoy the feeling of their generosity before you ask for anything else.

section_name: 09 Little tricks of big winners
chapter_summary: When you do someone a favor, wait a suitable amount of time before asking them to repay it, so they feel you did it out of friendship.

section_name: 09 Little tricks of big winners
chapter_summary: Parties are for pleasantries and good fellowship, not for confrontations. Even big players are polite to their enemies at a party.

section_name: 09 Little tricks of big winners
chapter_summary: The dining table is a safe haven where no unpleasant matters should be discussed. Positive brainstorming is acceptable, but tough business is not.

section_name: 09 Little tricks of big winners
chapter_summary: If you run into someone with whom you are in a sensitive negotiation or communication, keep the conversation light and do not bring up business.

section_name: 09 Little tricks of big winners
chapter_summary: If you need information from people, let them have their entire say first. Wait until their "tank is on empty" before you introduce your ideas.

section_name: 09 Little tricks of big winners
chapter_summary: When dealing with an emotional situation, hear the facts but empathize intensely with the emotions. Calming the emotional storm is often the only way to get to the facts.

section_name: 09 Little tricks of big winners
chapter_summary: When you make a mistake, it's not enough to just correct it. You must find a way for your "victim" to benefit, so they will be delighted you made the flub.

section_name: 09 Little tricks of big winners
chapter_summary: When you catch someone in a lie or deception, do not confront them directly unless it is your responsibility to do so. Let the person save face, then resolve to not deal with them again.

section_name: 09 Little tricks of big winners
chapter_summary: To get special attention from any service personnel in the future, send a complimentary letter or note about them to their boss.

section_name: 09 Little tricks of big winners
chapter_summary: When you agree with a speaker, be the first person in the audience to applaud or publicly commend them. This signals that you are also a leader.

chapter_name: 92 The Great Scorecard in the Sky
section_name: 09 Little tricks of big winners
chapter_summary: Understand that there is an invisible scorecard between any two people, and the player with the lower score must pay deference to the player with the higher score. Before any interaction, calculate who should defer to whom to avoid being thrown out of the game.
